ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question (27th February, 1998],

    "That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st April, 1998 to 31st March, 1999." - [Minister for Finance].

Column: 728



    Question again proposed.

    Mr Chuang Shaw Peng (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, for the benefit of those who were not present during my presentation yesterday, I beg your permission to give a summary of what I said. The main point that I put across was that the timeliness and accuracy of information for decision-making is extremely important in this fast-changing world. And this is even so in the preparation of a nation's Budget. I touched on the increasingly alarming reports of the banks' exposure to regional economies. Malaysian banks also sustained heavy losses.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, it looks like events are unfolding faster than information can be gathered, analysed and disseminated. Yesterday, we got the financial results of UOB. The figure for their classified loans for regional economies is $332 million, out of the total classified loans of the bank of $991 million. Since this is the first time the bank has made such a disclosure, there was no historical data with which I can compare and get the year-to-year difference. But it may be sufficient to surmise that the difference between the $991 million and $332 million, as just mentioned, was due to local loans, and the difference is about $660 million. Mr Speaker, Sir, $660 million classified local loans.

    A similar analysis of DBS Bank gives us a figure of $735 million for classified local loans. With just these two banks, the combined figure is a staggering $1.4 billion. I wish to highlight here that the $1.4 billion for the two banks must be telling us that there are many local enterprises who cannot service their loans any more.

    The figure will be bigger if we combine the results of all the big four, Hong Kong Bank, Standard Chartered, Citibank and other banks that lend to our companies. Further analysis shows that for UOB, the $332 million classified loan is out of the 19.7% of total loans, and $660 million is out of the 80% of total loans. I may

Column: 729

surmise that the total loans' current status is only half as good as those compared to regional loans. And my guess here is consistent with the survey results of the various associations that our local companies are not doing well. I hence call on the Government to get the banks to make quarterly reports, instead of half-yearly reports, to increase transparency and market efficiency, and to work more closely with the associations to feel the pulse and the health of our companies.

    Having cited these figures, I am concerned that the proposed Budget is not meeting the needs of the current economic situation. The market has reacted so. If the Government is not reacting fast enough, would we get into deeper trouble which will cost us more to get out? The slow reaction of Japanese Finance Ministry's officials to their country's economic problem and Japan's slow recovery has presented to us vividly a classic example of why lagging and conservative policies may not be ideal after all.

    Yesterday, I called on the Finance Minister to have a more expansionary Budget. I urge the Minister not to allow the current economic difficulties to deflect our long-term infrastructure development plans and, hopefully, it will not affect the construction of underground road systems and the facilities needed to push our vital economic sectors. As demonstrated by the first phase of our MRT project, kicking off big infrastructure projects during an economic downturn enables us to construct these facilities at bargain prices. We should capitalise on the current situation by building more MRTs and LRTs because construction costs are low.

    On another note, I would like to focus on one point which is related to private equity funds. Although there are now tax incentives for this industry, there is still no clear strategy by the Government to develop a vibrant private equity fund industry.

Column: 730



    So far, the Finance Ministry has given incentives for developing Singapore into Asia's premier fund management hub. This is to basically focus on promoting Singapore as a centre for managing Asian marketable securities investment portfolios of both Asian and Western clients, and for managing global marketable securities for clients. However, specific initiatives for developing Singapore as a hub for private equity fund management industry seem to be one thing in the new financial sector policy announcement. In this connection, we should note that the private equity fund management industry in Singapore is much less robust than in Hong Kong. There are much more new equity funds founded there every year. More funds are under management and more fund management companies have headquarters in Hong Kong than in Singapore. Singapore only captures a very small fraction of the private equity funds investing in the region, although we are strategically well located for such regional funds targeting for investment in the ASEAN countries.

    In this regard, what plans does the Finance Ministry have for the private equity fund management industry? What are the strategies in attracting more internationally reputable private equity fund managers or groups to establish their headquarters here?

    Now, many local enterprises are cash-squeezed, and news has it that Malaysian, Thai and Indonesian private companies are in dire need for capital injection. It is clear that this is an opportune time for Singapore to encourage more private equity funds, big or small, foreign or local, to have their headquarters in Singapore, so that there is rapid matching between private companies in need of funds and those who are willing to invest in them. Note that private equity funds not only have the advantage of not being able to make massive, rapid pull-out, compared to those involving marketable securities, it also fuels growth for many start-ups, as everybody has witnessed in Silicon Valley in the USA. This will be a big boost to entrepreneurship and is also consistent with Singapore's on-going strategy for regionalisation.

Column: 731



    So far, it may sound as if I am supporting the financial sector only. But actually a vibrant dynamic private equity industry would benefit our SMEs more than just the financial market. And this brings me to the next point.

    There is constant complaint among our SMEs that the Government's policies, though pro-business, have always been pro-MNC and pro-GLC only. EDB is the main Government body in charge of the promotion of SMEs and bringing our SMEs to the vision of Singapore 21. Yet there is no clear strategy outlined in this Budget regarding this. It may be an opportune time for the House to consider the reorganisation of EDB so that fresh ideas and new directions can be injected to promote SMEs to cater to the new possibilities in the fast-changing global economy. This rejuvenating effort can only be good for the nation.

    Yesterday, Mr Inderjit Singh said that Taiwan has weathered this crisis better than others because they have a strong SME economy. And I hope the Government will take a serious look at this.

    The last area I would like to touch is that I notice from this proposed Budget that no major amount is allotted for manpower training. And this is strange because many, many Members of this House have repeatedly emphasised the importance of retraining policy, and there was even talk about tripartite cooperation on training. Here, I call on the relevant Ministries to focus more on the specific plans to carry out training to avoid structural unemployment as seen in many developed countries.

    With the setting up of the Ministry of Manpower, I believe the policy of manpower training will be more comprehensive and effective. Accordingly, more funding should be provided as an off-Budget measure. Mr Speaker, Sir, it was reported in this House not too long ago that there are 700,000 workers in Singapore who have had only up to secondary two education. If we were to train 5% of them per year, namely, 35,000 workers, and it costs $2,000 per worker,

Column: 732

we will need $75 million in total per year. And that is a very slow retraining process, because at 5% per year, it will take us 20 years to retrain all our workers and many of whom would have retired by then. So I suggest that budget for training should be in the region of $100 million to $200 million so that we can cover 10-15% of the workforce per year. And I believe this will be more beneficial to the economy than the $130 million rebate in property tax given to a handful of developers, as rightly pointed out by Dr Lee Tsao Yuan yesterday.

    In summary, I believe that the Government should have their operation orders ready to avert a developing crisis, rather than wait for an emergency before thinking of remedial action. Through off-Budget measures, the Government can take the driver's seat in introducing more infrastructure projects, more manpower training, encouraging more private equity funds, working more closely with SMEs, so that we can get the buzz into our economy, as what our Senior Minister has judiciously called for. Perhaps then, the people may be better helped in getting prepared to weather this crisis.

    Mr Choo Wee Khiang (Jalan Besar)(In Mandarin): First, I would like to indicate my support for the Budget Statement.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, from the media reports, we can generally see that many in Singapore have expressed disappointment over this year's Budget. Some business people have expressed the view that they are completely lost as to why there are no off-Budget measures as announced by the Minister. The small and medium-sized businesses are even more so in this case. Generally, people feel that the Government must be more positive in helping the economy, the businessmen and to stimulate our economy so as to enable us to tide over the storm in Singapore. Right now, we are very disheartened about the effect brought about by the economic turmoil and it is quite reasonable that the business people expect the Government to announce rescue packages and measures for the people.

Column: 733



    I agree with Mr Leong Horn Kee that the Government must pay closer attention to the current developments and should work together with the local organisations in business and industry to maintain a continual dialogue with them. I hope that, if it is possible, the Government should immediately set up a Special Committee, a Special Task Force, to prepare for the rainy day. This Task Force or Special Committee should aim at helping the Government to provide views and collective wisdom, to collect feedback so that Singapore and the country can go through this storm. The members of this Committee should be representatives from the Manpower Ministry, Ministry of Finance, MTI and representatives of private sector organisations.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, apart from increasing the tax cut for income tax and interest tax, etc, I hope that the Government will help those first-time buyers of properties to give them special attention because these people who bought the properties for the first time normally have financial problem. In other words, they do not have adequate cash upfront to pay for the properties. So I do not know whether the Government is prepared to consider allowing such people to make use of their CPF money to pay for the first downpayment of 20%. Then the people who benefit will not be the first time property buyers but also others as well. At the same time, I hope that the Minister for Finance will allow the business community to understand why there is so much prudence in the present Budget. Many members of the business community feel that, as compared to our Budget, the Hong Kong budget appears to be more flexible and better able to help the business community to tide over the crisis.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, let me go to the next important topic. In this year's Budget, the emphasis is on education. I feel that at this time of economic and financial turmoil, highlighting and placing emphasis on education is only right. I feel that education is not only aimed at educating people in English, the Science subjects like Chemistry, Physics, etc, but equally

Column: 734

important is the need to bring up our children to become cultured, civilised citizens with traditions. In other words, we must also have moral education, physical education and community education for our children. If we over-emphasise on intellectual education, concentrate only on how many `A's the children can score, and neglect the other aspects of education, such as moral education, physical education, community education, then you may end up with negative results. These results would be the production of a new generation of people who care only for their own self-interest and utilitarian value of life but do not care about respect for the old, the teachers and become arrogant and swell-headed. They do not even know how to repay the society to serve the country and to be loyal to the country.

    In recent years, juvenile crimes seem to be mounting in Singapore. The question is: is it related to the lack of promotion of moral education in Singapore?

    Mr Speaker, Sir, this morning, the Lianhe Zaobao published an article by Mr Lee Ther Sen, who is an educationist. In the article, the importance and effect of moral education and community education is emphasised. The article highlighted one important point. He said that community education is social education. The problem to be solved is to correct the conflict of interest between the individual, the society, the country and the community. It is to overcome the problem of extreme individualism so as to provide social cohesion and harmony. So community education is not only a question of relation between the individuals and the society to promote solidarity, it is also an important key and a collective will to overcome difficulties and crisis. Therefore, he said that community education is an indispensable link of the five aspects of education which must be given its due respect and importance. I entirely agree with what he has said.

    I feel that, Mr Speaker, Sir, if we neglect this invisible asset, we will only do so at our own peril. We should not neglect the nurturing of our children in this aspect. We must bring up a next generation of

Column: 735

Singaporeans so that we do not produce zombies. Some people have described that our future generation will be just like zombies or robots. They only know Science, Biology and Chemistry. They do not know about their oriental traditions, culture and roots. They do not even know the virtues of the oriental societies. The Prime Minister, Mr Goh Chok Tong, has already mentioned in one of his recent speeches that we must not only emphasise intellectual education, we must equally emphasise the other aspects of education. I therefore hope that the Government will pay due attention to this aspect, ie, physical education and moral education to bring about a better, more suitable and relevant education system for Singapore, and with a proper strategy.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, sometimes I cannot help thinking whether we should have an overall comprehensive review of our education system, especially for the primary level. What is taught at the primary level might be an over-emphasis on intellectual education and forgetting about good citizenship, moral values and ethics. These are important lessons that they must learn for their foundation in life. At the same time, I do not know whether the Government or the Ministry of Education should think more about our mother tongue education. If our mother tongue education is not made more interesting and popular, then our children may not be able to directly understand and get a feel of our own culture and tradition. So I think it is necessary for the Government to review comprehensively the primary education. This kind of intangible asset is a very important motivating force for the progress of our country. Of course, we cannot live without money. But you also cannot live without these virtues. Without such virtues, I think the prospects of our country would be jeopardised.

    Mr Ong Kian Min (Pasir Ris): Thank you for allowing me to join in this debate. Sir, I rise to support the Budget Statement presented by the Minister for Finance.

    The current regional crisis has seen our political leaders and Government acting in a rational and sensible manner in dealing with the difficult and complex issues

Column: 736

confronting the region. This Budget is another example of the prudent approach that needs to be adopted to ride through this crisis. The Budget is conservative and prudent and rightly so, in the light of the present economic, political and social uncertainty facing the region as a whole. We must not lose sight of the big picture that we are in the midst of a regional crisis of unprecedented proportions. The outcome of this crisis is not at all clear and is impossible to predict because it is dependent on a multitude of factors and variables, many of which are beyond our control. We must be prepared for whatever situations that may arise. But, in the meantime, to dedicate resources for longer term strategic investment in defence, education, economic infrastructure and skills upgrading and the promotion of high growth industries.

    Whilst the dedication of resources for long-term strategic investment makes sense for the whole country as a whole, it sounds a bit hollow to the business people who are facing cash-flow problems and having difficulties in staying afloat in the short to medium term. Businesses would only benefit if they are still in business when these long-term investments bear fruit. All these improved economic infrastructure would mean nothing if the business folds up before then or is so sapped of energy and resources that they cannot take advantage of the eventual recovery.

    The issues confronting businesses are more short-term in nature. They are looking for and expecting something more from the Government to help them tide over these difficult periods and survive. They feel that the policy measures adopted in this Budget did not reflect the severity of the current situation and question whether the Government's assessment of the situation was based on old statistics compiled a few months ago. But if one had just visited the Travel Fair over the last weekend and see the hoards of people snapping up holiday packages, one would never have imagined that we are in the midst of a regional crisis.

    Sir, notwithstanding the difference in assessment, I am gratified to note that the

Column: 737

Minister for Finance has assured us that the Government will monitor the regional environment and economic conditions vigilantly and keep in touch with the private sector. Should the circumstances turn for the worse, other off-Budget measures could be taken to address the situations as and when they develop. However, for the present, people are shouting for help.

    Many businesses and workers had hoped for a cut in tax rates. It seems logical that during hard times like these, the Government should help by collecting less taxes so that people can take home more. To someone who received a smaller bonus or no bonus at all last year, or got a small or no pay increase this year, the natural tendency is for him to wish for a cut in income tax or an increase in tax rebate to cushion the impact of the reduction in income. But we must not forget that the Government has already introduced substantial tax cuts over the last 12 years. Currently, only about 30% of individuals pay personal income tax and corporate income tax is paid by companies which are doing well enough to generate the profit. These individuals and profitable companies should not shy away from their responsibility at a time like this.

    This reminded me of the thoughts of our Senior Minister on the fragility of a multi-racial society which he shared with journalists and diplomats at a dinner in June 1996. He pondered the question of whether the Singaporean would share with his neighbour who is of a different race in times of severe stress and starvation. If there is only one bowl of rice, will the Singaporean share with his neighbour? We are not in the kind of crisis which the Senior Minister had in mind. Far from it. But are the more fortunate Singaporeans willing to share with their fellow Singaporeans who are not so fortunate? This is a test of our cohesion and our ability to stay as one nation in times of difficulty. The top income earners who are fortunate enough not to lose their

Column: 738

jobs and corporations that are making profits must do their part by contributing their share in building a better tomorrow.

    Sir, I am also told that the two major problems that business people are presently confronted with are weak regional exports and low domestic demands for their goods and services, and the high cost of doing business in Singapore compared to our neighbours. On the first problem of weak demand, there is little that we can do right now if the other regional countries cut back on their imports because of their economic downturn.

    On the domestic front, consumers have every reason to be careful in their spending during times of uncertainty. Some friends of mine have told me that in austere times like this, they have to do their marketing and shopping outside Singapore, where their Singapore dollar carries far greater purchasing power and goes much further. Another group of friends I chanced upon at the Travel Fair last weekend said that they could only afford to take a short holiday this year in the region, because the tax rebate was only 5%. If there had been a cut in tax rates or larger rebate given to them, they would have more money to spend on a longer holiday to Europe or to the United States. These comments lead me to wonder whether our retailers would benefit from any fiscal measures to increase disposable income at this point in time.

    On the second problem of high cost, we cannot compete with the other regional countries based on cost alone. Before this crisis, they were Asia's tiger economies capable of producing and enjoying many years of high economic growth. As a result of this crisis, their currencies have devalued and the cost of their exports had correspondingly decreased. If and when they get their acts together, restore confidence, put their economies back on track, they will emerge as formidable competitors. We need creative solutions to tackle our problems. We need to be more productive and highly skilled so that customers can find good value in the goods and services that we produce.

Column: 739



    Training and skills upgrading for our local workforce are therefore very important. However, training and skills upgrading are often seen by businesses as cost items and often the first expense to be cut when business is down. Manpower is our only resource we have as a nation. We must continually upgrade the skills of our workforce. In a downturn such as this, many companies are experiencing the slowdown in business activities and workers are not fully occupied. Instead of keeping the workers idle or retrenching them, sensible employers would want to take this opportunity to release them for training or retraining. But many can ill afford the training cost in difficult times like this when budgets are tight. More should by done by the Government to help defray the cost of training and to further streamline the procedure for making claims and reimbursement to ease the employers' cash flow situations.

    Training and skills upgrading should not be confined to the low skilled workers, but must be carried out at all levels, especially at the time when globalisation and global competition compel us to attract the best and the brightest to come here to work, at the top end of the workforce, the professionals and the managerial executives. We can expect very high calibre foreign talents coming here from the more developed countries. Top talents are a mobile lot. They go where their services are needed and where there is money to be made. For example, during the boom years of this region, many project finance experts worked out of Singapore to advise on projects in this region. Now that these projects are shelved, these experts have been redeployed to other parts of the world where there are still projects to be financed. In the meantime, the debt restructuring, corporate recovery and insolvency experts are being redeployed from other parts of the world to this region because their expertise is in short supply here and they are needed to do work. We cannot therefore be forever dependent on foreign talents, just as we cannot be dependent on foreign borrowings to drive our economy. Although talent, unlike capital cannot be moved away at the mere push of a button

Column: 740

or click of the mouse, they can still swiftly take flight when the country becomes unattractive. We must therefore build up our core competencies, skills and expertise, just as we have built up strong monetary reserves over time. Whilst we need foreign talents now, our local workforce must take the opportunity to assimilate knowledge, upgrade our skills and be competent to do the job ourselves, in the event that we are left to pick up the pieces.

    Whilst much has been said about retraining and upgrading of our older less skilled workers, I feel that not much attention has been given to white collar workers, even though they face the same uncertainty and problems of retrenchment. I know a young graduate bank officer who has worked for 5-8 years as an Assistant Manager in the corporate banking department of a foreign bank. New banking facilities are now put on hold. She is fearful that she would be retrenched because of a world-wide cost cutting programme implemented by her head office. I asked her what she would do if indeed she were retrenched. She replied that she had no idea, as there was an over supply of people with her skills. Perhaps she would sell insurance. If the worst comes to the worst, she may have to give piano lessons to earn a living.

    We would like to believe that being educated, they should be able to take care of themselves and find alternative employment for themselves. But my feeling is that many, especially the younger ones, simply do not know what to do. Many who are in their early to mid-30s have joined a tight labour market after the last recession in 1985. Their skills were very much in demand but they enjoyed good job prospects and uninterrupted high earnings for more than a decade. This is the first difficult period that they are encountering in their career.

    Apart from the employees in the financial services sector, and banks are streamlining their operations and cutting back, similar difficulties are faced by conveyancing lawyers, who are affected by the drop in property transactions, property agents in a lacklustre property market and many others. I would urge the

Column: 741

Government to do more and provide more guidance to help them cope with the crisis. At the same time, I believe managerial executives and skilled workers must also be realistic. Instead of twiddling their thumbs and waiting for the return of the good old days, they must proactively retrain to do other work or find work elsewhere. Employers and corporate executives of search firms have lamented in the past that Singaporean executives were spoilt and fussy, and it was very difficult to get a Singaporean to be posted to a developing country like China, Vietnam or Myanmar. Singaporean executives can no longer be choosy. Like our counterparts from the developed countries who go where the business is, they must be ready and prepared to be redeployed to places where we can leverage on our expertise and make full use of it. This is especially so now when there are many good investments to be found in the region and skilled people are critically needed to manage them and bring out the true value in these investments.

    Sir, a clear underlying message in this budget is that in view of the uncertainty, we must keep our resources and reserves so that these can be used at the appropriate time. Ever since independence, we have been constantly reminded of the need to save for a rainy day. We have done so consistently and built up strong reserves. Many are now asking whether this is the time to use what we have saved for so many years. The present situation has been described as the worst in decades. Is this not exactly the situation which we have consciously and painstakingly prepared for? Have the rains which we have prepared for arrived? Government already has various programmes in place which provide assistance in funding for both the retail and tourism sectors. For instance, Government has been enhancing retail infrastructure and providing upgrading in areas such as stock control, shop management and staff retraining to improve the competitiveness and resilience of our retailers. For the tourism sector, the Singapore Tourism Board also helps industry members to obtain financial and manpower training assistance from schemes such as the Innovation Development Scheme and Initiatives for New Technology (INTECH) Scheme. In addition, approved tourism projects can also qualify for Industrial Building Allowances, Investment Allowances on approved expenditure as well as property tax concessions.

    Mr Lim Swee Say has asked whether more funds could be allocated to the EDB and other economic agencies, to enable them to take the opportunity to attract

Column: 833

more investments into Singapore. I would like to assure Mr Lim that the Government is always open to opportunities to attract investments into Singapore. In FY98, $176 million will be provided for EDAS grants, compared with $131 million in FY97, a 34% increase. We are prepared to increase the funding if this should prove necessary.

    Dr Vasoo has asked for rebates or concessions to be given to promote savings. As a general rule, we do not want to distinguish between different types of income for tax purposes, as it could otherwise result in economic distortions, for example, it could skew investment decisions if interest income was favoured over, say, dividend income. There is also the question of equity. Generally, those who derive the same income should pay the same amount of taxes. If we were to selectively exempt certain types of income, we could have an anomaly of high income earners paying very little taxes if their income is mainly from tax-exempt sources.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee and Mr Ravindran have suggested that we provide relief for mortgage loans, similar to what Hong Kong did in its FY98 budget. I should point out that in Hong Kong, most people live in privately owned housing which is very expensive. Because of Hong Kong dollar's peg to the US dollar, interest rates are also much higher than in Singapore. Hong Kong home owners, therefore, pay hefty mortgage rates, hence mortgage relief is needed. In the case of Singapore, more than 85% of our population live in HDB flats and they already enjoy subsidies, not only on the purchase price of their flats, but also on the low mortgage interest payments. Therefore, there is no need to provide further tax reliefs on mortgage loans.

    Mr Ahmad Magad has asked that a multi-tier corporate tax system, with lower tax rates for smaller companies, be adopted. This was raised in last year's Budget debate and I would like to reiterate that a multi-tier tax system will create opportunities for tax planning, such as a breaking-up of companies to pay less tax. To guard against these, elaborate tax rules would be needed, which will lead to higher tax compliance cost. Having a low

Column: 834

tax rate may also not help smaller companies in their start-up phase anyway, since they will not be paying much taxes in the first place during their start-up phase.

    Dr Teo Ho Pin has asked why the property tax rebate was extended only to industrial and commercial properties, but not residential properties. The property tax rebate was granted to ease the cost of business. In the case of individuals and households, it is more meaningful to extend income tax rebate and rebates on service and conservancy charges and rental charges. Home owners are already taxed at a lower concessionary tax rate of 4% on the annual value of their properties. Further, with the property tax rebates given since 1994 to offset GST, currently the majority of HDB households living in 1- to 4-room flats do not pay any property tax.

    Dr Teo also spoke on the unhappiness of house owners in having to resolve disputes over their annual value of properties with IRAS. It is the duty of the Chief Assessor to ensure that the annual value conforms to the statutory definition of being the estimated annual rental that the property can fetch in the market. Home owners can object to any adjustments of their annual value within 21 days of the notice to adjust the value. Home owners simply need to complete a one-page form stating their grounds of objection. The Chief Assessor will review and adjust annual values accordingly if there are valid grounds of objection. If home owners disagree with the valuation, they can appeal to an independent Valuation Review Board.

    Mr Tay Beng Chuan and Dr Wang Kai Yuen expressed concern over the recent upward revision on the annual values of some properties. Since January this year, IRAS has been actively reviewing properties with a view to reducing their annual values, where warranted. To-date, IRAS has reviewed some 22,000 cases and reduced the annual rental values by more than $78 million. This reduction in annual values came from 37% of the cases reviewed. 63% had their annual values retained and only 1% of the cases had

Column: 835

their annual values increased based on market evidence. IRAS will continue to further reduce the annual values where the market warrants it. Property owners who have reduced their rentals could also inform IRAS so that IRAS could initiate a review and reduce the annual values promptly and accordingly.

    Mr Inderjit Singh has commented that there is too much Government intervention in the property market. He commented that Government should just set the overall framework to guard against asset inflation and leave the market to just find its own level. Mr Singh, Mr Simon Tay and Mr Chuang Shaw Peng also echoed the sentiment that too much may have been given to developers which are still expected to make reasonable profits even after making loss provisions on unsold units.

    The Government's long-term strategy is to supply sufficient land at a steady pace to meet the aspirations of Singaporeans to own private residential properties. However, given the cyclical nature of the property market, it is inevitable that property prices will rise and fall. The Government will not intervene in the property market except when it is necessary to avoid excessive market volatility. This is because extreme ups and downs in the property market could have a severe and long lasting impact on the real economy. Hence, Government introduced anti-speculation measures in May 1996 to prick the speculative bubble and to cool down the residential property market. Similarly, in the present downturn, attributable to the regional economic turmoil, Government has adjusted its land sale programme to avoid exacerbating an over-supply situation. It is not the Government's intention to ensure that developers make a profit. Like any other businesses, they will have to assess business risks and face the consequences.

    Mr Sinnakaruppan has commented that many younger Singaporeans who are graduates find that they still cannot meet the 20% cash payment for the purchase of private property despite the falling property prices. He suggested that the Government should allow for a reduced

Column: 836

10% cash payment for first-time owners of private property. Mr Choo Wee Khiang and Mr Zulkifli both suggested allowing the use of CPF for the down-payment.

    The 80% limit on bank financing of property purchases is a prudential measure to ensure that the banking sector is not over-exposed to the property sector and that home owners are not heavily geared and hence vulnerable to a fall in property prices. In countries such as Hong Kong and Malaysia, even stricter limits are imposed on banks in financing property purchases. It would not be prudent to relax the 80% limit, even selectively for first-time buyers. To do so would reduce the buffer which banks have in the event of default where the pledged properties have to be disposed of at lower prices. CPF savings cannot be used as the buffer because they go back to the buyer's CPF account if the property is resold. Furthermore, any concession to be granted to only a select group of buyers could easily be subject to abuse. Home buyers should therefore consider their financial position carefully before purchasing a property.

    Mr Sin Boon Ann has commented that GLCs should be subject to greater accountability to make sure that public money invested in GLCs is well spent and that there should be greater disclosure on their investments as recommended by the Public Accounts Committee. Government is conscious that a considerable amount of public money has been invested in our GLCs. I would therefore like to assure Members of the House that our GLCs have been profitable and represent good investments of public money. Although some of the investments made by our GLCs have not turned out as expected, we should not over react. Many are public listed companies and their accounts are open to public scrutiny. Most of these have performed well over the years and have contributed substantially to public coffers.

    Dr Vasoo has asked whether greater efficiency has been achieved as a result of the corporatisation of Government agencies and whether the interest of the consumers have been protected. The objective of the

Column: 837

corporatisation programme is to enable the service provider to operate as a business entity so that it will be efficient, bottom-line driven and be responsive to changes in a competitive environment and the demands of its customers. Towards this end, Government has been liberalising the telecommunication industry in a gradual manner and we have clearly seen and experienced the benefits in terms of more competitive pricing and greater consumer choice. However, in situations where there is a corporatised monopoly, as in the case of Singapore Power, the Government regulatory body, in this case, PUB, would play a critical role in regulating tariff charges to ensure that the charges are fair. I would like to assure Members of this House that our regulatory bodies are vigilant in ensuring that the interests of the consumers are safeguarded. During the transitory period between corporatisation and the introduction of competition, the regulator will monitor the situation closely to keep tab on charges and service quality.

    A few Members have asked whether Government would freeze utilities charges and other Government fees to reduce the burden on businesses and individuals. Government fees and charges are revised only to keep pace with cost increases. If cost had not increased, fees and charges would also not increase. Our policy has been to revise fees and charges regularly so that the increases can be kept small. The revisions ensure that the Government services are properly priced to guard against misallocation of resources. However, the Government will continue to monitor the situation closely and will review the fees and charges if there is a need to do so.

    Both Mr Leong Horn Kee and Mr Inderjit Singh have commented on the depreciation of regional currencies against the Singapore dollar and said that it is now an opportune time to escalate the pace of regionalisation and promote the establishment of manufacturing bases in the region. The recent devaluation of regional currencies relative to the Singapore dollar does provide opportunities for our

Column: 838

companies to further invest in the region. Whilst the Government can give assistance to our companies by highlighting the opportunities that are available and facilitating the investments, ultimately the companies themselves must assess the risks involved and decide whether it is commercially viable for them to expand their activities in the region. For those who are willing and able to undertake further regional investments, there already exists a comprehensive range of tax and financial incentives to assist them. Incentives such as the Regionalisation Financing Scheme, Local Enterprise Finance Scheme, Overseas Enterprise Incentive and Overseas Investment Incentive have been used extensively.

    Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon has asked whether Government would consider allowing workers to use a portion of their CPF savings for an unemployment benefits scheme as part of a crisis package to be invoked only when there is a severe economic downturn. There are no plans to set up such a scheme at present. The proposal has to be carefully considered in view of the long-term implications on the labour market and costs of employment. In times of economic recession, the best way to help workers is to help them get jobs and upgrade their skills so that they remain employable. Currently, there are more than 450,000 foreign workers in Singapore. In an extreme situation, we can adjust the dependency ratio to reduce the influx of foreign workers and to assist our own retrenched workers to find alternative employment. These measures would help our workers cope without having to establish an unemployment benefits scheme as a basic safety net. Experience in other countries serves to remind us that the best security net for Singaporeans is not unemployment or welfare benefits but constant growth and manpower development.

    Mrs Yu-Foo has also commented that as manpower development is critical, the Government should allocate sufficient resources to the new Ministry of Manpower (MOM). As part of the effort to build up Singapore's global competitiveness, Government has decided to

Column: 839

place all manpower planning, development and management issues under the charge of a single Ministry. As a central agency, the new Ministry will be in a better position to coordinate all critical manpower planning and management issues. The new Ministry will also put greater emphasis on collaboration with its partners, which include the private sector, the unions and Government agencies, so that it will be able to align the efforts of all stakeholders to our national manpower vision. Government is committed to the development of manpower and will ensure that sufficient financial resources are made available to MOM. If additional funds are required, my Ministry is prepared to consider such requests.

    Mdm Claire Chiang has noted that MCD had the second lowest budget and had urged the Government to allocate a larger budget for the community services sector. She further observed that MCD's budget was even lower than that of the Police Division under MHA. Instead of allocating a huge budget to MHA whose focus is on remedial action, resources should be shifted to preventive action undertaken by MCD. But I would like to point out that MCD's budget alone is not representative of the Government's spending on community development. Besides Community Development, Government's spending on Education, Health, Information and the Arts, Environment as well as Public Housing all contribute to the social and community well-being of Singapore. Total Government's spending on social and community services, which include these six named areas, will amount to $10.3 billion or 37.6% of FY1998 Budget. The community and social services sector in fact will receive the highest allocation of resources in FY1998. Further, it is incorrect to say that MCD's focus is on taking preventive action while that of MHA is on remedial action. A very significant proportion of the Ministry of Home Affairs' resources has always been devoted to preventive programmes, such as crime prevention, fire safety and drug education. We should see spending in these programmes as complementary to the other programmes in the social and community services sector.

    Mdm Chiang would also be pleased to know that MCD would be embarking on a national study on the state of our families and another on the impact of maids on childcare. In addition, MCD has increased the number of neighbourhood centres which include childcare centres, youth drop-in programmes and centres for elderly services. MCD will also be looking into the manpower needs for the social service sector and will be working closely with the voluntary organisations in this area.

    Mr Simon Tay has urged the Government not to neglect building up the softer aspects of life through involvement in charity and the arts, and has suggested that Government maintain its commitment in these areas during these hard times. I would like to assure the Member that sufficient funds have been provided to arts and culture and community development and that there is no cut-back on Government's commitment in these two areas. For the voluntary welfare organisations (VWOs) of the Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Community Development, Government is providing $140 million of grants in FY1998 as compared to $96 million provided in FY1997. As for the Ministry of Information and the Arts, the FY1998 budget is $381 million as compared to $318 million in FY1997.

    In the past two days of debate, several Members have spoken on the subject of bond-breaking by public sector scholars. I do not propose to comment on this issue. However, DPM BG Lee will be making a Ministerial Statement on this subject tomorrow after Question Time.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, let me sum up by emphasising to Members of this House that the Government is fully aware of the extent of the economic slowdown and is carefully monitoring its impact on the population and the different sectors of the economy. The crisis has not run its full course and we must maintain a cool head to anticipate and deal with developments as yet unknown. In this respect, I thank the Members of this House for signposting possible areas of concern. At the same time, we should use the opportunity to

improve our competitive weaknesses and position ourselves for the impending recovery of the region. Together, I am confident that we will weather the storm and learn valuable lessons which will stand us in good stead for the challenges of the future. [Applause.]
